question: Question 104 What is curl of the vectorfield [latex]2x^2y i+5z^2j-4yzk[/latex]?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{curl}\bar{F}&=\begin{vmatrix} \bar{i} & \bar{j} & \bar{k}\\ \frac{\partial }{\partial x} & \frac{\partial }{\partial y} & \frac{\partial }{\partial z}\\ 2x^2y & 5z^2 & -4yz \end{vmatrix} \\ &=\bar{i}(-4z-10z)-\bar{j}(0-0)+\bar{k}(0-2x^2) \\ &= 14zi-2x^2k \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 105 The following inequality is true for all x close to 0. [latex]2-\frac{x^2}{3} \lt \frac{xsinx}{1-cosx} \lt 2[/latex] What is the value of [latex]\lim_{x \to 0}\frac{xsinx}{1-cosx}[/latex]?
solution: [latex]\lim_{x \to 0}\frac{x \sin x}{1-\cos x}[/latex] [latex]\lim_{x \to 0}\frac{\frac{\sin x}{x}}{\frac{1-\cos x}{x^2}}=\frac{1}{\frac{1}{2}}=2[/latex]

question: Question 106 The Laplace transform of [latex]\sinh (at)[/latex] is
solution: [latex]L(\sinh (at))=\frac{a}{s^2-a^2}[/latex]

question: Question 107 Euclidean norm (length) of the vector [latex][4\; -2\; -6]^T[/latex] is
solution: Let [latex]X=\begin{bmatrix} 4\\ -2\\ -6 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Norm} \; X&=||X|| \\ &=\sqrt{(4)^2 +(-2)^2 +(-6)^2} \\ &= \sqrt{16+4+36}\\ &= \sqrt{56} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 108 Consider the ordinary differential equation [latex]x^2\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}-2x\frac{dy}{dx}+2y=0[/latex]. Given the values of y(1)=0 and y(2)=2, the value of y(3) (round off to 1 decimal place), is ____

Question 109 Consider two functions: [latex]x=\psi ln\phi[/latex] and [latex]y=\phi ln\psi[/latex]. Which one of the following is the correct expression for [latex]\frac{\partial \psi }{\partial x}[/latex]?
solution: Taking the partial derivative with respect to x for the two equations, we get [latex]\begin{aligned} 1&=\frac{\partial \psi }{\partial x}\ln \phi +\frac{\psi }{\phi }\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial x}\\ 0&=\frac{\phi }{\psi }\frac{\partial \psi }{\partial x}+ \ln \psi \frac{\partial \phi }{\partial x} \end{aligned}[/latex] From above two equations, we get [latex]\frac{\partial \psi }{\partial x}=\frac{\ln \psi }{\ln \phi \ln \psi -1}[/latex]

question: Question 110 A one-dimensional domain is discretized into N sub-domains of width [latex]\Delta x[/latex] with node numbers i=0,1, 2, 3,...,N. If the time scale is discretized in steps of [latex]\Delta t[/latex], the forward-time and centered-space finite difference approximation at [latex]i^{th}[/latex] node and [latex]n^{th}[/latex] time step, for the partial differential equation [latex]\frac{\partial v}{\partial t}=\beta \frac{\partial^2 v}{\partial x^2}[/latex] is
solution: Given [latex]\frac{\partial V}{\partial t}=\beta \frac{\partial^2 V}{\partial x^2}[/latex] The centred space finite difference approximation at [latex]i^{th}[/latex] node [latex]n^{th}[/latex] time step is [latex]\frac{V_i^{n+1}-V_i^n}{\Delta t}=\beta \left [ \frac{V_{i+1}^n -2V_i^n +V_{i-1}^n}{(\Delta X)^2} \right ][/latex]

question: Question 111 Which one of the following is NOT a correct statement?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Let}\;y &=\sqrt[x]{x}\;\;x \gt 0 \\ y&=x^{\frac{1}{x}} \\ \ln y&=\ln x^{\frac{1}{x}} \\ \ln y &=\frac{1}{x} \ln x \\ \frac{1}{y} \frac{dy}{dx}&=\frac{1}{x^2}-\frac{\ln x}{x^2} \\ \frac{1}{y} \frac{dy}{dx}&=\frac{1}{x^2}(1-\ln x) \\ \frac{dy}{dx}&= \frac{y}{x^2}(1-\ln x)\\ \text{put}\;\; \frac{dy}{dx}&=0\Rightarrow \frac{y}{x^2}(1-\ln x)=0 \\ \Rightarrow \; x&=e \\ \text{Now,}\;\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} &=\frac{-y}{x^3}-\frac{2y}{x^3}(1- \ln x)+\frac{1}{x^2}(1-\ln x)\frac{dy}{dx} \\ \text{At}\; x &=e, \\ \frac{d^2y}{dx^2}&=\left ( \frac{-y}{x^3} \right )_{x=e}-\frac{2y}{x^3}(1-\ln e)+\frac{1}{x^2}(1- \ln e)\frac{dy}{dx} \\ &= \left ( \frac{-x^{\frac{1}{x}}}{x} \right )_{at\; x=e}\\ &=\frac{-e^{\frac{1}{e}}}{e}=0\\ \frac{d^2y}{dx^2}\; & \text{has maximum at }\; x=e \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: The function [latex]\sqrt[x]{x},(x \gt 0)[/latex], has the global maxima at [latex]x=e[/latex]
options.B: The function [latex]\sqrt[x]{x},(x \gt 0)[/latex], has the global minima at [latex]x=e[/latex]
options.C: The function [latex]x^3[/latex] has neither global minima nor global maxima
options.D: The function |x| has the global minima at x=0

question: Question 112 For a small value of h, the Taylor series expansion for [latex]f(x+h)[/latex] is
solution: We know that Taylor series for small h of f(x + h) is, [latex]f(x+h)=f(x)+hf'(x)+\frac{h^2}{2!}f''(x)+\frac{h^3}{3!}f'''(x)+...[/latex]

question: Question 113 Consider a two-dimensional flow through isotropic soil along x direction and z direction. If h is the hydraulic head, the Laplace's equation of continuity is expressed as
solution: The Laplace's equation of continuity for two dimensional flow in a soil is expressed as: [latex]k_x\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial x^2}+k_z\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial z^2}=0[/latex]... for anisotropic soil [latex][k_x\neq k_z][/latex] : [latex]\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial x^2}+\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial z^2}=0[/latex]... for isotropic soil [latex][k_x = k_z][/latex]

options.B: [latex]\frac{\partial h}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial h}{\partial x}\frac{\partial h}{\partial z}+\frac{\partial h}{\partial z}=0[/latex]
options.D: [latex]\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial x^2}+\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial x \partial z}+\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial z^2}=0[/latex]

question: Question 114 Which one of the following is correct?
solution: [latex]\lim_{x \to 0}\left ( \frac{\sin 4x}{\sin 2x} \right )=\lim_{x \to 0}\left ( \frac{\frac{\sin 4x}{x}}{\frac{\sin 2x}{x}} \right )=\frac{4}{2}=2[/latex] and [latex]\lim_{x \to 0}\left ( \frac{\tan x}{x} \right )=1[/latex]

question: Question 115 The value (up to two decimal places) of a line integral [latex]\int_{c}\vec{F}(\vec{r}).\vec{dr},\: \: for\: \vec{F}(\vec{r})=x^{2}\hat{i}+y^{2}\hat{j}[/latex] along C which is a straight line joining (0,0) to (1,1) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \bar{F}&=x^{2}\bar{i}+y^{2}\bar{j} \\ \int \bar{F}.d\bar{r}&=\int \left ( x^{2}\bar{i}+y^{2}\bar{j} \right ).\left ( dx\bar{i}+dy\bar{j} \right ) \\   &=\int x^{2}dx+y^{2}dy\\ (0, 0)\text{ to }&(1, 1) \text{ line is }y=x\\  &=\int x^{2}dx+x^{2}dx=\int_{0}^{1}2x^{2}dx \\   &=2\left.\begin{matrix} \left ( \frac{x^{3}}{3} \right ) \end{matrix}\right|_{0}^{1}=\frac{2}{3}=0.666 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 116 The rank of the following matrix is [latex]\begin{pmatrix} 1 &1 &0 &-2 \\ 2 & 0 &2 &2 \\ 4 &1 &3 &1 \\ \end{pmatrix}[/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}   A&=\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & 0 &-2 \\ 2 & 0 & 2 &2 \\ 4 & 1 & 3 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\   R_{2}&\rightarrow R_{2}-2R_{1},\: R_{3}\rightarrow R_{3}-4R_{1} \\ &   \begin{pmatrix} 1 &1 &0 & -2\\ 0 & -2 & 2 & 6\\ 0 & -3 & 3 & 9 \end{pmatrix} \\   R_{3} & \rightarrow R_{3}-\frac{3}{2}R_{2} \\    & \begin{pmatrix} 1 &1 &0 & -2\\ 0 & -2 & 2 & 6\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \end{aligned}[/latex] Number of non zero rows [latex]=2[/latex] Rank of [latex]A=2[/latex]

question: Question 117 The laplace transform F(s) of the exponential function ,[latex]f(t)=e^{at}\; when \; t\geq 0[/latex], where a is a constant and (s-a)[latex]\gt [/latex]0, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L(e^{at}) &=\frac{1}{s-a} \\ L(e^{at}) &=\int_{0}^{\infty }e^{-st}e^{at}dt \\ &= \int_{0}^{\infty }e^{-(s-a)t}dt\\ &= \left.\begin{matrix} \frac{e^{-(s-a)t}}{-(s-a)} \end{matrix}\right|_{0}^{\infty }\\ &=-\frac{1}{s-a}(0-1)\\ &=\frac{1}{s-a} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 118 The matrix [latex]\begin{pmatrix} 2 &-4 \\ 4 &-2 \end{pmatrix}[/latex] has
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned}  A&=\begin{bmatrix} 2 & -4\\ 4 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \\  \left | A-\lambda I \right |&=0 \\ \begin{vmatrix} 2-\lambda & -4\\ 4 & -2-\lambda \end{vmatrix}&=0 \\ -4-2\lambda +2\lambda +\lambda ^{2}+16&=0 \\ \lambda ^{2}+12&=0 \\    \lambda &=\pm 2\sqrt{3}i\text{ (Complex eigen values)} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex](1) \;\;   \lambda =2\sqrt{3}i[/latex] Consider [latex]\left ( A-\lambda I \right )X=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{bmatrix} 2-2\sqrt{3}i &-4 \\ 4 & -2-2\sqrt{3}i \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 2-2\sqrt{3}ix_{1}&=4x_{2} \\    \frac{x_{1}}{4}&=\frac{x_{2}}{2-2\sqrt{3}i} \\    \begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2} \end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix} 4\\ 2-2\sqrt{3}i \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex](2)\;\;  \lambda =-2\sqrt{3}i[/latex] Consider [latex]\left ( A-\lambda I \right )X=0 [/latex] [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 2+2\sqrt{3}i & -4\\ 4 & -2+2\sqrt{3}i \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 2+2\sqrt{3}ix_{1}&=4x_{2} \\   \frac{x_{1}}{4}&=\frac{x_{2}}{2+2\sqrt{3}i} \\   \begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x-{2} \end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix} 4\\ 2+2\sqrt{3}i \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Complex eigen values and complex eigen vectors.

question: Question 119 The quadratic equation [latex]2x^{2}-3x+3=0[/latex] is to be solved numerically starting with an initial guess as [latex]x_{0}=2[/latex] . The new estimate of x after the first iteration using Newton-Raphson method is ______
solution: Given [latex]\begin{aligned}  f\left ( x \right )&=2x^{2}-3x+3, x_{0}&=2 \\    {f}'\left ( x \right )&=4x-3 \end{aligned}[/latex] By Newton-Rapshon [latex] \begin{aligned}   x_{1}&=x_{0}-\frac{f\left ( x_{0} \right )}{{f}'\left ( x_{0} \right )} \\    &=2-\frac{2\left ( 2 \right )^{2}-3\left ( 2 \right )+3}{4\left ( 2 \right )-3} \\    &=2-\frac{5}{5}=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 120 Probability (up to one decimal place) of consecutively picking 3 red balls without replacement from a box containing 5 red balls and 1 white ball is ______
solution: Probability, [latex]\bar{P}=\frac{5}{6}\times \frac{4}{5}\times \frac{3}{4}=\frac{1}{2}=0.5[/latex]

question: Question 121 A probability distribution with right skew is shown in the figure. The correct statement for the probability distribution is
solution: [latex]t_{L}\lt t_{mean}[/latex]=Curve is skew to right. Mode [latex]\lt[/latex] mean i.e., Mean [latex]\gt[/latex] median and mode Mean is greater than the mode and the median.This is common for a distribution that is skewed to the right [i.e., bunched up toward the left and a 'tail' stretching toward the right].

options.B: Mean is greater than median but less than mode
options.C: Mean is greater than median and mode

question: Question 122 The graph of a function f(x) is shown in the figure. For f(x) to be a valid probability density function, the value of h is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{3}f\left ( x \right )dx &=1 \\ \int_{0}^{1}f\left ( x \right )dx+\int_{1}^{2}f\left ( x \right )dx+\int_{2}^{3}f\left ( x \right )dx &=1 \\ \frac{h}{2}+\frac{2h}{2+\frac{3h}{2}} &=1 \\ 6h &=2 \\ \Rightarrow\; \; h &=\frac{1}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 123 The solution of the equation [latex]x\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}+y=0[/latex] passing through the point (1,1) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}x\frac{dy}{dx}+y&=0 \\ x\frac{dy}{dx}&=-y \\ \frac{dy}{y}&=-\frac{dx}{x} \\ \int \frac{1}{y}dy&=\int \frac{-1}{x}dx \\ \ln y&=-\ln x+c\\ \text{when } y&=1, x=1\\  c&=0\\ \Rightarrow  \;\; y&=\frac{1}{x}=x^{-1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 124 The solution at ( up to three decimal places) at x=1 of th euation [latex]\frac{d^{2}y}{dx^2}+2\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}+y=0[/latex] subject to boundary condition y(0)=1 and [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}(0)=-1[/latex] is______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}\left ( D^{2}+2D+1 \right )y&=0 \;\;  \left ( \therefore \; \text{Roots are }-1,-1\right ) \\    CF&=\left ( C_{1}+C_{2}x \right )e^{-x} \\    y&=C_{1}e^{-x}+C_{2}xe^{-x} \;\;...(i) \\ y\left ( 0 \right )&=1  \;\;\;1=C_{1}        \;\;\;...(ii) \\    {y}'&=C_{1}e^{-x}+C_{2}\left ( e^{-x}-xe^{-x} \right ) \\ {y}'\left ( 0 \right )&=-1,  \;\;\;-1=-C_{1}+C_{2}     \;\;...(iii)\\ \text{From eq. } & \text{ (ii) and (iii),}\\    C_{1}&=1,\, C_{2}=0 \\ \therefore \;\;   y&=e^{x}\\ \text{At } x=1, y&=e^{-1}=\frac{1}{e}=0.368\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 125 The solution at x=1,t=1 of the partial differential equation [latex]\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2}=25 \frac{\partial^2u}{\partial t^2}[/latex] subject to boundary conditions u(0)=3x and [latex]\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}(0)=3[/latex] is
Question 126 The value of the integral [latex]\int_{0}^{\pi}x\cos ^{2}x\: dx[/latex] is
solution: The value of [latex]\begin{aligned}&\int_{0}^{\pi }x\cos ^{2}x\, dx \\    &=\int_{0}^{\pi } \left ( \frac{x}{2}+\frac{x\cos 2x}{2} \right )dx \\   &=\left.\begin{matrix} \frac{x^{2}}{4} \end{matrix}\right|_{0}^{\pi }+\frac{1}{2}\left ( \frac{x\sin 2x}{2}+\frac{\cos 2x}{4} \right ) \\    &=\frac{\pi ^{2}}{4}+\frac{1}{2}\left \{ \left ( 0+\frac{1}{4} \right )-\left ( 0+\frac{1}{4} \right ) \right \} \\    &=\frac{\pi ^{2}}{4}+\frac{1}{2}\left ( \frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{4} \right ) \\    &=\frac{\pi ^{2}}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 127 At the point x= 0, the function [latex]f(x)=x^{3}[/latex] has
solution: [latex]f\left ( x \right )=x^{3}[/latex] at [latex]x=0[/latex] At [latex]x=0[/latex], the function [latex]y=x^{3}[/latex] has neither minima nor maxima.

options.D: neither local maximum nor local minimum

question: Question 128 For the given orthogonal matrix Q, [latex]Q=\begin{bmatrix} 3/7 &2/7 &6/7\\ -6/7 &3/7 &2/7\\ 2/7 &6/7 &-3/7 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The inverse is
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \left | Q \right |&=\frac{3}{7}\left ( -\frac{9}{49}-\frac{12}{49} \right )-\frac{2}{7}\left ( \frac{18}{49}-\frac{4}{49} \right )+\frac{6}{7}\left ( \frac{-36}{49}-\frac{6}{49} \right ) \\  &=-1 \\   Adj. \; Q&=\begin{bmatrix} -\frac{21}{49} & \frac{42}{49} &-\frac{14}{49} \\ -\frac{14}{49}& -\frac{21}{49} & -\frac{42}{49}\\ -\frac{42}{49} & -\frac{14}{49} & \frac{21}{42} \end{bmatrix} \\ \therefore\;\;    Q^{-1}&=\frac{Adj\: Q}{\left | Q \right |}=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{3}{7} & -\frac{6}{7} & \frac{2}{7}\\ \frac{2}{7} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{6}{7}\\ \frac{6}{7} & \frac{2}{7} & -\frac{3}{7} \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned} [/latex] Or [latex]\because[/latex] Q is orthogonal [latex]\therefore  \;\; Q^{-1}=Q^{T}[/latex]

question: Question 129 Which one of the following matrices is singular?
solution: Option (A): [latex]\left | A \right |=6-5=1[/latex] Option (B): [latex]\left | A \right |=9-4=5[/latex] Option (C): [latex]\left | A \right |=12-12=0[/latex] Option (D): [latex]\left | A \right |=8-18=-10[/latex] Hence matrix (C) is singular.

question: Question 130 Consider the following second-order differential equation: [latex]{y}''-4y'+3y=2t-3t^{2}[/latex] The particular solution of the differential equations is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} {y}''-4{y}'+3y&=2t-3t^{2} \\ \left ( D^{2}-4D+3 \right )y&=2t-3t^{2} \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} P.I.&=\frac{1}{D^{2}-4D+3}\left ( 2t-3t^{2} \right ) \\ &=\frac{1}{\left ( 1-D \right )\left ( 3-D \right )}\left ( 2t-3t^{2} \right ) \\ &=\left ( \frac{1/2}{1-d}-\frac{1/2}{3-D} \right )\left ( 2t-3t^{2} \right ) \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left ( 1-D \right )^{-1}\left ( 2t-3t^{2} \right ) \\ &-\frac{1}{6}\left ( 1-\frac{D}{3} \right )^{-1}\left ( 2t-3t^{2} \right ) \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left ( 1+D+D^{2} \right )\left ( 2t-3t^{2} \right ) \\ &\times \frac{1}{6}\left ( 1+\frac{D}{3}+\frac{D^{2}}{9} \right )\left ( 2t-3t^{2} \right ) \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left ( 2t-3t^{2}+D\left ( 2t-3t^{2} \right ) +D^{2}\left ( 2t-3t^{2} \right ) \right ) \\ &-\frac{1}{6}\left ( 2t-3t^{2} \right ) \\ & +\frac{D\left ( 2t-3t^{2} \right )}{3}+\frac{D^{2}}{9}\left (2t-3t^{2} \right) \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left [ 2t-3t^{2}+2-6t-6 \right ]- \\ &\frac{1}{6}\left [ 2t-3t^{2}+\frac{2-6t}{3}+\frac{-6}{9} \right ] \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left ( -4-4t-3t^{2} \right )-\frac{1}{6}\left ( -3t^{2} \right ) \\ &=-2-2t-t^{2}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 131 If [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 5\\ 6& 2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] and [latex]B=\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 7\\ 8& 4 \end{bmatrix}[/latex], [latex] AB^{T}[/latex] is equal to
solution: [latex]AB^{T}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &5 \\ 6 &2 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 7 & 8\\ 7& 4 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 38 & 28\\ 32 & 56 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

question: Question 132 Consider the following definite integral: [latex]I=\int_{0}^{1}\frac{(\sin^{-1}x)^2}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}dx[/latex] The value of integral is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}\text{Let, } \sin^{-1}x&=t \\   \frac{dx}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}&=dt \\   I&=\int_{0}^{\pi /2}t^{2}dt \\ &=\left [ \frac{t^{3}}{3} \right ]_{0}^{\pi /2} \\ &=\frac{\pi ^{3}}{24} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 133 The tangent to the curve represented by [latex]y=x\ln x[/latex] is required to have [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex] inclination with the x-axis. The coordinates of the tangent point would be
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \tan \theta &=\frac{dy}{dx}&=\ln x+1 \\  \tan 45^{\circ}&=\ln x+1 \\   1&=\ln x+1 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; \ln x&=0 \\ \therefore \;\;  x&=1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Putting [latex]x=1[/latex] in the eq. of curve, we get [latex]y=0[/latex].

question: Question 134 A two-faced fair coin has its faces designated as head (H) and tail (T). This coin is tossed three times in succession to record the following outcomes: H, H, H. If the coin is tossed one more time, the probability (up to one decimal place) of obtaining H again, given the previous realizations of H, H and H, would be______
Question 135 The divergence of the vector field [latex]V\, =x^{2}i+2y^{3}j+z^{4}k[/latex] at [latex]x=1, y=2, z=3[/latex] is_______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{V}&=x^{2}\hat{i}+2y^{3}\hat{j}+z^{4}\hat{k} \\ \vec{\bigtriangledown }.\vec{V}&=\left [ \frac{\partial }{\partial x}\hat{i}+\frac{\partial }{\partial y}\hat{j}+\frac{\partial }{\partial z}\hat{k} \right ].\left [ x^{2}\hat{i}+2y^{3}\hat{j}+z^{4}\hat{k} \right ] \\   &=2x+6y^{2}+4z^{3}\\ &\text{At }\left ( 1,2,3 \right )\\ \vec{\bigtriangledown }\vec{V}&=2+6\left ( 2 \right )^{2}+4\left ( 3 \right )^{3} \\   &=134 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 136 Let w=f(x,y), where x and y are functions of t. Then, according to the chain rule, [latex]\frac{dw}{dt}[/latex] is equal to
solution: [latex]  w=f\left ( x, y \right )[/latex] By Chain rule, [latex]  \frac{dw}{dt}=\frac{\partial w}{\partial x}\times \frac{dx}{dt}+\frac{\partial w}{\partial y}\times \frac{dy}{dt}[/latex]

options.B: [latex]\frac{\partial w}{\partial x}\frac{\partial x}{\partial t}+\frac{\partial w}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial t}[/latex]

question: Question 137 Consider the following simultaneous equations (with [latex]c_{1} \; and \; c_2[/latex] being constants): [latex]3x_{1}+2x_{2}=c_{1}[/latex] [latex]4x_{1}+x_{2}=c_{2}[/latex] The characteristic equation for these simultaneous equations is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}    \left [ A \right ]&=\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2\\ 4 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \\    \left [ A-\lambda I \right ]&=\begin{bmatrix} 3-\lambda & 2\\ 4 & 1-\lambda \end{bmatrix} \\    \left | A-\lambda I \right |&=0 \\   \left ( 3-\lambda \right )\left ( 1-\lambda \right )-8&=0 \\    3-4\lambda +\lambda ^{2}-8&=0 \\     \lambda ^{2}-4\lambda -5&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 138 A particle of mass 2 kg is travelling at a velocity of 1.5 m/s. A force [latex]f(t)=3t^{2}[/latex]  (in N) is applied to it in the direction of motion for a duration of 2 seconds, where t denotes time in seconds. The velocity (in m/s, up to one decimal place) of the particle immediately after the removal of the force is _____
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned}m=2 kg, \; V_{0}&=1.5\: m/sec \\  \int_{0}^{t}F\left ( t \right )dt &= m\left ( V-V_{0} \right ) \\  \int_{0}^{2}3t^{2}dt &= 2\left ( V-1.5 \right ) \\  \left [ t^{3} \right ]_{0}^{2} &= 2\left ( V-1.5 \right ) \\ \Rightarrow \;\;  \left ( 8-0 \right ) &= 2\left ( V-1.5 \right ) \\   V&=5.5\: m/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 139 Consider the equation [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d} t}=3t^{2}+1[/latex] with u=0 at t=0. This is numerically solved by using the forward Euler method with a step size [latex]\Delta t= 2[/latex]. The absolute error in the solution at the end of the first time step is_________
solution: [latex]  \begin{aligned}   \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d} t}&=3t^{2}+1 \\ f\left ( u,\: t \right )&=3t^{2}+1 \\ u_{0}&=0 \\ t_{0}&=0 \\ \Delta t&=2\\ &\text{By Euler's method} \\     u_{1}&=u_{0}+hf\left ( u_{0}t_{0} \right )  & t_{1}&=t_{0}+h \\     &=u_{0}+h\left ( 3t^{2}_{0}+1 \right )   &  &=0+2 \\     &=0+2\left ( 3\left ( 0 \right )^{2}+1 \right )   &  &=2 \\     &=2 \end{aligned}[/latex] After first iteration u=0 when t=2, [latex]\begin{aligned}    \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d} t}&=3t^{2}+1 \\     du&=\left ( 3t^{2}+1 \right )dt \\    \int du&=\int_{0}^{2}\left ( 3t^{2}+1 \right )dt \\     u&=\left.\begin{matrix} \left ( 3\frac{t^{3}}{3}+t \right ) \end{matrix}\right|_{0}^{2} \\     &=8+2=10 \end{aligned}[/latex] Absolute error = Exact value - approx value [latex]=10-2 =8[/latex]

question: Question 140 Consider the matix [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -1\\ 4 & 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is TRUE for the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of this matrix?
solution: [latex]    A=\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -1\\ 4 & 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] Characteristic equation is [latex]\left | A-\lambda I \right |=0 [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}     \begin{vmatrix} 5-\lambda & -1\\ 4 & 1-\lambda \end{vmatrix}&=0 \\ 5-5\lambda -\lambda +\lambda ^{2}+4&=0 \\     \lambda ^{2}-6\lambda +9&=0 \\         \lambda &=3,\, 3 \end{aligned}[/latex] Algebraic multiplicity of eigen value 3 is 2. It has only one independent eigen vector exists.

options.A: Eigenvalue 3 has a multiplicity of 2, and only one independent eigenvector exists.
options.B: Eigenvalue 3 has a multiplicity of 2, and two independent eigenvectors exist.
options.C: Eigenvalue 3 has a multiplicity of 2, and no independent eigenvector exists.
options.D: Eigenvalues are 3 and -3, and two independent eigenvectors exist.

question: Question 141 The solution of the equation [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} Q}{\mathrm{d} t}+Q=1[/latex] with [latex]Q=0[/latex] at [latex]t=0[/latex] is
solution: [latex]   \frac{\mathrm{d} Q}{\mathrm{d} t}+Q=1[/latex] Comparing with standard form, [latex]   I.F.=e^{\int 1dt}=e^{t}[/latex] Solution is, [latex]\begin{aligned}   Q.e^{t}&=\int 1.e^{t}dt=e^{t}+C \\    Q&=1+Ce^{-t} \;\;...(i) \\ \text{When }t&=0, Q=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\;   0&=1+C \\ \Rightarrow \;\;   C&=-1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, [latex]Q\left ( t \right ) =1-e^{-t}[/latex]

question: Question 142 For the function [latex]f(x)=a+bx, \; \; 0\leq x\leq 1,[/latex] to be a valid probability density function, which one of the following statements is correct?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty }^{\infty }f\left ( x \right )dx &= 1 \\ \int_{0}^{1}\left ( a+bx \right )dx &= 1 \\ \left.\begin{matrix} \left ( ax+\frac{bx^{2}}{2} \right ) \end{matrix}\right|_{0}^{1}&=1 \\ a+\frac{b}{2}&=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 143 [latex]\lim_{x \to 0} (\frac{\tan x}{x^{2}-x})[/latex] is equals to
solution: [latex]\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{\tan x}{x^{2}-x}[/latex] (Applying L'Hospital rule) [latex]  \lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{\sec ^{2}x}{2x^{2}-1}=\frac{\sec ^{2}0}{0-1}=\frac{1}{-1}=-1[/latex]

question: Question 144 Consider the following partial differential equation: [latex]3\frac{\partial^2 \phi }{\partial x^2}+B\frac{\partial^2 \phi }{\partial x \partial y} + 3\frac{\partial^2 \phi }{\partial y^2}+4\phi =0[/latex] For this equation to be classified as parabolic, the value of [latex]B^{2}[/latex] must be_______
solution: Given that the partial differential equation is parabolic. [latex]\therefore  \;\; B^{2}-4AC=0   [/latex] Here [latex]A=3 , C=3[/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; B^{2}-4\left ( 3 \right )\left ( 3 \right )=0   [/latex] [latex]  B^{2}-36=0 [/latex] [latex]  B^{2}=36[/latex]

question: Question 145 The reaction rate involving reactants A and B is given by [latex]-k[A]^{\alpha }[B]^{\beta }[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is valid for the reaction to be first-order reaction?
solution: The order of reaction is the exponent to which its concentration term in the rate equation is raised. Rate, [latex] r=K\left [ A \right ]^{\alpha }\left [ B \right ]^{\beta }[/latex] For the first order reaction, [latex] \alpha +\beta =1[/latex]

question: Question 146 Let x be a continuous variable defined over the interval ([latex]-\infty ,\infty[/latex]), and [latex]f(x)=e^{-x-e^{-x}}[/latex]. The integral [latex]g(x)=\int f(x)dx[/latex] is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f\left ( x \right )&=e^{-x-e^{-x}}= e^{-x}.e^{-e^{-x}} \\  y\left ( x \right )&=\int f\left ( x \right )dx=\int e^{-x}.e^{-e^{-x}}dx\\ \text{Let }  e^{-x}&=t \\  -e^{-x}dx&=dt \\ \int f\left ( x \right )dx&=\int e^{-t}.\left ( -dt \right ) \\    &=\frac{e^{-t}}{-1}.\left ( -d \right ) \\    &=e^{-t} \\    &=e^{-\left ( e^{-x} \right )} \\ &=e^{-e^{-x}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 147 The number of parameters in the univariate exponential and Gaussian distributions, respectively, are
solution: In exponential, [latex]    f\left ( x \right )=\lambda e^{-\lambda x}[/latex]; [latex]   x=0[/latex] The parameter is [latex]\lambda[/latex] In Gaussian, [latex]f(x)=\frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2\pi }}e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left ( \frac{x-\mu }{\sigma } \right )^{2}}; \;\; -\infty \lt x\lt \infty[/latex] The parameters are [latex]\mu[/latex] and [latex]\sigma[/latex].

question: Question 148 The matrix P is the inverse of a matrix Q. If [latex]I[/latex] denotes the identity matrix, which one of the following options is correct?
solution: Given that P is inverse of Q. [latex] \begin{aligned}   P&=Q^{-1}  & P&=Q^{-1} \\    PQ&=Q^{-1}Q &  QP&=QQ^{-1} \\    PQ&=I &  QP&=I \\ \therefore    PQ&=QP=I \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 149 The quadratic approximation of [latex]f(x)=x^{3}-3x^{2}-5[/latex] at the point x=0 is
solution: The quadratic approximation of [latex]f(x)[/latex] at the point [latex]x=0[/latex] is, [latex] \begin{aligned} f\left ( x \right )&=\: f\left ( 0 \right )+\frac{x}{1!}{f}'\left ( 0 \right )+\frac{x^{2}}{2!}{f}''\left ( 0 \right ) \\   &=\left ( -5 \right )+x\left \{ 0 \right \}+\frac{x^{2}}{2}\left \{ -6 \right \} \\ &=-3x^{2}-5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 150 The area between the parabola [latex]x^{2}=8y[/latex] and the straight line y=8 is ______.
solution: Parabola is [latex]x^{2}=8y[/latex] [latex]   y=\frac{x^{2}}{8}[/latex] and straight is [latex]y=0[/latex] At the point of intersection, we have, [latex]  \frac{x^{2}}{8}=8 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow   x=-8,\, 8 \text{ and } y=8\geq y=\frac{x^{2}}{8} [/latex] [latex]  \therefore[/latex] Required area is [latex]\int_{x=-8}^{8}\left ( 8-\frac{x^{2}}{8} \right )dx [/latex] [latex] =2\int_{0}^{8}\left ( 8-\frac{x^{2}}{8} \right )dx[/latex] ([latex]\because \;\; 8-\frac{x^{2}}{8}[/latex] is even function) [latex]=2\left [ 8x-\frac{x^{3}}{24} \right ]_{0}^{8}=\frac{256}{3}=85.33[/latex] sq. units

question: Question 151 The angle of intersection of the curves [latex]x^{2}=4y[/latex] and [latex]y^{2}=4x[/latex] at point (0, 0) is
solution: Given curve, [latex] \begin{aligned} x^{2}&=4y \;\; ...(i)\\  y^{2}&=4y \;\;...(ii)\\  2x&=4\frac{dy}{dx} \\ \Rightarrow  \;\; \left ( \frac{dy}{dx} \right )_{\left ( 0\,, 0 \right )}&=0=m_{1}\\  2y\frac{dy}{dx}&=4 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; \left ( \frac{dy}{dx} \right )_{\left ( 0\, ,0 \right )}&=\infty =m_{2}\\ \text{Let }m_{2}&=\frac{1}{{m}'} , \text{ where }{m}'=0 \\ \tan \theta &=\left | \frac{m_{1}-m_{2}}{1+m_{1}m_{2}} \right | \\&=\left | \frac{m_{1}{m}'-1}{{m}'+m_{1}}\right | \\&=\left | \frac{0-1}{0+0} \right |=\infty \\ \Rightarrow \;\; \theta &=\frac{\pi }{2}=90^{\circ}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 152 If f(x) and g(x) are two probability density functions, [latex]f(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix}
\frac{x}{a}+1 & :-a\leq x \lt 0\\ 
-\frac{x}{a}+1 & :0\leq x\leq a\\ 
 0& : otherwise
\end{matrix}\right.[/latex] [latex]g(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} -\frac{x}{a} & :-a\leq x \lt 0\\ \frac{x}{a} & :0\leq x\leq a\\ 0& : otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] Which one of the following statements is true?
solution: Mean of f(x) is E(x) [latex]=\int_{-a}^{0}x\left ( \frac{x}{a}+1 \right )dx+\int_{0}^{a}x\left ( \frac{-x}{a}+1 \right )dx[/latex] [latex]=\left ( \frac{x^{3}}{3a}+\frac{x^{2}}{2} \right )_{-a}^{0}+\left ( \frac{-x^{3}}{3a}+\frac{x^{2}}{2} \right )_{0}^{a}=0[/latex] Variance of f(x) is [latex]E\left ( x \right )^{2}-\left \{ E\left ( x \right )^{2} \right \}[/latex] where, [latex]E\left ( x \right )^{2}=\int_{-a}^{0}x^{2}\left ( \frac{x}{a}+1 \right )dx+\int_{0}^{a}x^{2}\left ( \frac{-x}{a}+1 \right )dx[/latex] [latex]=\left ( \frac{x^{4}}{4a}+\frac{x^{3}}{3} \right )_{-a}^{0}+\left ( \frac{-x^{4}}{4a}+\frac{x^{3}}{3} \right )_{0}^{a}=\frac{a^{3}}{6}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; [/latex]Variance is [latex]\frac{a^{3}}{6}[/latex] Next, mean of g(x) is E(x) [latex]=\int_{a}^{0}s\left ( \frac{-x}{a} \right )dx+\int_{0}^{a}x\left ( \frac{x}{a} \right )dx=0[/latex] Variance of g(x) is [latex]E\left ( x^{2} \right )-\left \{ E\left ( x \right )^{2} \right \}[/latex], where, [latex]E\left ( x^{2} \right )=\int_{-a}^{0}x^{2}\left ( \frac{-x}{a} \right )dx+\int_{0}^{a}x^{2}\left ( \frac{x}{a} \right )dx=\frac{a^{3}}{2}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; [/latex]Variance is [latex]\frac{a^{3}}{2}[/latex] [latex]\therefore [/latex] Mean of f(x) and g(x) are same but variance of f(x) and g(x) are different.

options.A: Mean of f(x) and g(x) are same; Variance of f(x) and g(x) are same.
options.B: Mean of f(x) and g(x) are same; Variance of f(x) and g(x) are different.
options.C: Mean of f(x) and g(x) are different; Variance of f(x) and g(x) are same.
options.D: Mean of f(x) and g(x) are different; Variance of f(x) and g(x) are different.

question: Question 153 Consider the following linear system [latex]x+2y-3z=a[/latex] [latex]2x+3y+3z=b[/latex] [latex]5x+9y-6z=c[/latex] This system is consistent if a,b and c satisfy the equation
Question 154 What is the value of [latex]\lim_{\begin{matrix} x\rightarrow 0\\ y\rightarrow 0 \end{matrix}} \frac{xy}{x^{2}+y^{2}}[/latex] ?
solution:
(i) [latex]\lim_{x\rightarrow \infty }\frac{xy}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\lim_{y\rightarrow \infty }\left ( \frac{0}{0^{2}+y^{2}} \right )=0[/latex] (i.e., put [latex]x=0[/latex] and then [latex]y=0[/latex]) (ii) [latex]\lim_{x\rightarrow 0 y\rightarrow 0}\frac{xy}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\left ( \frac{0}{x^{2}+0} \right )=0[/latex] (
i.e., put [latex]y=0[/latex] and then [latex]x=0[/latex]) (iii)[latex]\lim_{x\rightarrow 0 y\rightarrow 0}\frac{xy}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{x\left ( mx \right )}{x^{2}+m^{2}x^{2}}[/latex] (i.e., put [latex]y=mx[/latex]) [latex]  \lim_{x\rightarrow \infty }\left ( \frac{m}{1+m^{2}} \right )=\frac{m}{1+m^{2}}[/latex] which depends on m.

question:
Question 155 X and Y are two random independent events. It is known that [latex]P(X)=0.40[/latex] and 
[latex]P(X\cup Y^{C})=0.7[/latex]. Which one of the following is the value of [latex]P(X\cup Y)[/latex] ?
solution: [latex]\; \; \; \; P\left ( X\: \cup \: Y^{c} \right )=0.7[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; P\left ( X \right )+P\left ( Y^{c} \right )-P\left ( X \right )P\left ( Y^{c} \right )=0.7[/latex] (Since X, Y are independent events) [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; P\left ( X \right )+1-P\left ( Y \right )-P\left ( X \right )\left \{ 1-P\left ( Y \right ) \right \}=0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; P\left ( X \right )-P\left ( X\: \cap \: Y \right )=0.3\; \; \; \; \; \; ...\left ( i \right )[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; P\left ( X\: \cup \: Y \right )=P\left ( X \right )+P\left ( Y \right )-P\left ( X\: \cap \: Y \right )[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; =0.4+0.3=0.7[/latex]

question:
Question 156 The Fourier series of the function, [latex]\begin{matrix}
f(x) & =0 & -\pi \lt x \leq 0 \\ 
 f(x) &=\pi-x & 0 \lt x \lt \pi
\end{matrix} [/latex] in the interval [latex][-\pi ,\pi ][/latex] is [latex]f(x)=\frac{\pi }{4}+\frac{2}{\pi }\left [ \frac{\cos x}{1^{2}}+\frac{\cos 3x}{3^{2}}+\cdots\: \cdots \ \cdots \right ][/latex] [latex]+ \left [ \frac{\sin x}{1}+\frac{\sin 2x}{2}+\frac{\sin 3x}{3}+\cdots \: \cdots\: \cdot \right ][/latex] The convergence of the above Fourier series at x = 0 gives
solution: The function is [latex]f(x)=0[/latex] [latex]  -p\lt x\leq 0 [/latex] [latex]    =p-x,\, 0 \lt x \lt \pi [/latex] And Fourier series is, [latex]f\left ( x \right )=\frac{\pi }{4}+\frac{2}{\pi }\left [ \frac{\cos x}{1^{2}}+\frac{\cos 3x}{3^{2}}+\frac{\cos 5x}{5^{2}}+... \right ]+\left [ \frac{\sin x}{1}+\frac{\sin 2x}{2}+\frac{\sin 3x}{3}+... \right ]    ...\left ( i \right )[/latex] At x=0, (a point of discontinuity), the fourier series converges to [latex]\frac{1}{2}\left [ f\left ( 0^{-1} \right )+f\left ( 0^{+} \right ) \right ][/latex] where [latex]f\left ( 0^{-} \right )=\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\left ( \pi -x \right )=\pi [/latex] Hence, eq. (i), we get, [latex]  \frac{\pi }{2}=\frac{\pi }{4}+\frac{2}{\pi }\left [ \frac{1}{1^{2}}+\frac{1}{3^{2}}+... \right ] [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow   \;\; \frac{1}{1}+\frac{1}{3^{2}}+\frac{1}{5^{2}}+...\frac{\pi ^{2}}{8}[/latex]

question: Question 157 The optimum value of the function [latex]f(x)=x^{2}-4x+2[/latex] is
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned}  {f}'&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\;  2x-4&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\;  x&=2 \text{ (stationary point)}\\   {f}''\left ( x \right )&=2 \gt 0 \\ \Rightarrow\;\; f(x)& \text{ is minimum at } x=2\end{aligned}[/latex] i.e., [latex]\left ( 2 \right )^{2}-4\left ( 2 \right )+2=-2 [/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] The optimum value of [latex]f(x)[/latex] is [latex]-2[/latex] (minimum).

question: Question 158 The spot speeds (expressed in km/hr) observed at a road section are 66, 62, 45, 79, 32, 51, 56, 60, 53, and 49. The median speed (expressed in km/hr) is ________. (Note: answer with one decimal accuracy)
solution: Median speed is the speed at the middle value in series of spot speeds that are arranged in ascending order. 50% of speed values will be greater than the median 50% will be less than the median. Ascending order order of spot speed studies are 32, 39, 45, 51, 53, 56, 60, 62, 66, 79 Median speed=[latex]\frac{53+56}{2}[/latex]=54.5 km/hr

question: Question 159 The respective expressions for complimentary function and particular integral part of the solution of the differential equation [latex]\frac{d^4 y}{d x^4}+3\frac{d^2 y}{d x^2}=108 x^{2}[/latex] are
solution: D.E. is [latex]\left ( D^{4}+3D^{2} \right )y=108x^{2},\, D=\frac{d}{dx}[/latex] A.E. [latex] m^{4}+3m^{2}=0 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow  \;\; m^{2}\left ( m^{2}+3 \right )=0 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\; m=0,\, 0,\, \pm \sqrt{3}i [/latex] [latex] \therefore\;\; CF=\left ( c_{1}+c_{2}x \right )+c_{3}\sin \left ( \sqrt{3}x \right )+c_{4}\cos \left ( \sqrt{3}x \right)[/latex] and [latex]\begin{aligned} PI&=\frac{1}{D^{4}+3D^{2}}\left ( 108x^{2} \right ) \\  &=\frac{1}{3D^{2}\left [ 1+\frac{D^{2}}{3} \right ]}\left ( 108x^{2} \right ) \\ &=\frac{36}{D^{2}}\left [ 1+\frac{D^{2}}{3} \right ]^{-1}\left ( x^{2} \right ) \\  &=\frac{36}{D^{2}}\left [ 1-\frac{D^{3}}{3}+... \right ]\left ( x^{2} \right )\\ &=\frac{36}{D^{2}}\left [ x^{2}-\frac{1}{3}\left ( 2 \right )+0 \right ] \\  &=\int \int \left ( 36x^{2}-\frac{2}{3} \right )dx\, dx \\  &=36\left ( \frac{x^{4}}{\left ( 4 \right )\left ( 3 \right )}-\frac{2}{3}\frac{x^{2}}{3\left ( 2 \right )\left ( 1 \right )} \right ) +c\\ &=3x^{4}-12x^{2}+c \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 160 The area of the region bounded  by the parabola [latex]y=x^{2}+1[/latex] and the straight line [latex]x+y=3[/latex] is
solution: At the point of intersection of the curves, [latex]y=x^{2}+1[/latex] and [latex]x+y=3[/latex] i.e., [latex]y=3-x,[/latex] we have, [latex] \begin{aligned} x^{2}+1&=3-x \\ \Rightarrow \;\; x^{2}+x-2&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; x=-2,\: 1 & \text{ and }3-x\geq x^{2}+1\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Required area is [latex]\iint_{R} dydx[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}    &=\int_{1}^{x=-2}\left [ \int_{y=x^{2}+1}^{3-x}dy \right ]dx \\    &=\int_{-2}^{1}\left \{ 3-x \right \}-\left ( x^{2}+1 \right )dx \\    &=\left ( \frac{-x^{3}}{3}-\frac{x^{2}}{2}+2x \right )_{-2}^{1}=\frac{9}{2}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 161 The value of [latex]\int_{0}^{\infty }\frac{1}{1+x^{2}}dx+\int_{0}^{\infty }\frac{\sin x}{x}dx[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{\infty }\frac{1}{1+x^{2}}dx&= \left [ \tan^{-1}x \right ]_{0}^{\infty } \\    &=\tan^{-1}\infty \tan^{-1}0 =\frac{\pi }{2}\\ \text{and } L\left ( \sin x \right )&= \frac{1}{s^{2}+1} \\ \Rightarrow \;\; L\left ( \frac{\sin x}{x} \right )&= \int_{s}^{\infty }\frac{1}{s^{2}+1}dx\\ &\text{(Using "division by x")}\\   &= \left [ \tan^{-1}s \right ]_{s}^{\infty } \\   &=\tan^{-1}\infty -\tan^{-1}\left ( s \right ) \\ &=\cot^{-1}\left ( s \right ) \\ \Rightarrow \; \int_{0}^{\infty }e^{-sx}\frac{\sin x}{x}dx&= \cot^{-1}\left ( s \right ) \\   \text{(Using definition }&\text{of Laplace transform)}\\ \text{Put }s&=0, \text{ we get}\\  \int_{0}^{\infty }\frac{\sin x}{x}dx&= \cot^{-1}\left ( 0 \right )=\frac{\pi }{2} \\  \frac{1}{1+x^{2}}dx+\int_{0}^{\infty }\frac{\sin x}{x}dx&=\pi \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 162 Probability density function of a random variable X is given below [latex]f(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 0.25 \; if \; 1\leq x\leq 5\\ 0 \; \; otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] [latex]P\left ( X\leq 4 \right )[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} p\left ( x\leq 4 \right ) &=\int_{-\infty }^{4}f\left ( x \right )dx \\ &=\int_{-\infty }^{1}\left ( 0 \right )dx+\int_{1}^{4}\left ( 0.25 \right )dx+\int_{4}^{\infty }\left ( 0 \right )dx \\ &= \frac{1}{4}\left ( x \right )_{1}^{4}=\frac{1}{4}\left ( 4-1 \right )=\frac{3}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 163 The solution of the partial differential equation [latex]\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}=\alpha \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2}[/latex] is of the form
solution: The PDE [latex]\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}=\alpha \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2}   \;\;...(i)[/latex] Solution of (i) is, [latex]   u\left ( x,t \right )=\left ( A\cos px+B\sin px \right )Ce^{-p^{2}\alpha t}[/latex] Put [latex] -p^{2}\alpha =k[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\;  p=\sqrt{-\frac{k}{\alpha }}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{\alpha }}i[/latex] Putting value of p in eq.(i), [latex]\begin{aligned}u\left ( x,t \right )&=\left ( A\cos \sqrt{\frac{k}{\alpha }}x+b\sin h\sqrt{\frac{k}{\alpha }}x \right )Ce^{kt} \\  &=Ce^{kt}\left [ A\left \{ \frac{e^{\sqrt{\frac{k}{\alpha }}x}+e^{-\sqrt{\frac{k}{\alpha }}x}}{2} \right \}+B\left \{ \frac{e^{\sqrt{\frac{k}{\alpha }}x}-e^{-\sqrt{\frac{k}{\alpha }}x}}{2} \right \} \right ] \\  &=Ce^{kt}\left [ e^{\sqrt{\frac{k}{\alpha }}x}\left \{ \frac{A+B}{2} \right \}+e^{-\sqrt{\frac{k}{\alpha }}x}\left \{ \frac{A-B}{2} \right \} \right ] \\  &=Ce^{kt}\left [ c_{1}e^{\sqrt{\frac{k}{\alpha }}x}+c_{2}e^{-\sqrt{\frac{k}{\alpha }}x} \right ] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 164 Type II error in hypothesis testing is

options.A: acceptance of the null hypothesis when it is false and should be rejected
options.B: rejection of the null hypothesis when it is true and should be accepted
options.C: rejection of the null hypothesis when it is false and should be rejected
options.D: acceptance of the null hypothesis when it is true and should be accepted

question: Question 165 If the entries in each column of a square matrix M add up to 1, then an eigen value of M is
solution: Consider the '[latex]2\times 2[/latex]' square matrix [latex]M=\begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\;  \lambda ^{2}-\left ( a+d \right )\lambda +\left ( ad-bc \right )=0 \;\;...(i)[/latex] Putting [latex]\lambda =1[/latex], we get 1-(a+d)+ad-bc=0 1-a-d+ad-(1-d)(1-a)=0 1-a-d+ad-1+a+d-ad=0 0=0 which is true. [latex]\therefore \;\;\lambda =1[/latex] satisfied the eq.(i) but [latex]\lambda =2,3,4[/latex] does not satisfy the eq.(i). For all possible values of a, d.

question: Question 166 The type of partial differential equation [latex]\frac{\partial^2 P}{\partial x^2} + \frac{\partial^2 P}{\partial y^2} +3\frac{\partial^2 P}{\partial x \partial y } +2\frac{\partial P}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial P}{\partial y}=0[/latex] is
solution: Comparing the given equation with the general form of second order partial differential equation, we have A=1, B=3, C=1 [latex]\Rightarrow\; B^{2}-4AC=5\gt0 [/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] PDE is Hyperbola.

question: Question 167 Newton-Raphson method is to be used to find root of equation [latex]3x-e^{x}+\sin x=0[/latex]. If the initial trial value for the root is taken as 0.333, the next approximation for the root would be _________
solution: According to Newton-Raphson Method: [latex]  \begin{aligned}  x_{N+1}&=X_{N}-\frac{f\left ( X_{N} \right )}{{F}'\left ( X_{N} \right )} \\    f\left ( x \right )&=3x-e^{x}+\sin x \\    {f}'\left ( x \right )&=3-e^{x}+\cos x \\ \Rightarrow  \;\;  X_{1}&=X_{0}-\frac{f\left ( 0.333 \right )}{{f}'\left ( 0.333 \right )} \\    &=0.333-\frac{3\times 0.333-e^{0.333}+\sin 0.333}{3-e^{0.333}+\cos 0.333} \\ \therefore    \;\; X_{1}&=0.36 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 168 For step-size, [latex]\Delta x=0.4[/latex], the value of following integral using Simpson's 1/3 rule is _________. [latex]\int_{0}^{0.8}(0.2+25x-200x^{2}+675x^{3}-900x^{4}+400x^{5})dx[/latex]
solution: [latex]a=0, b=0.8, \Delta x=0.4 [/latex] [latex]f\left ( x \right )=0.2+25x-200x^{2}+675x^{3}-900x^{4}+400x^{5}[/latex] By Simpson's 1/3 Rule, [latex] \begin{aligned} y\left ( x \right )&=\int_{0}^{0.8}\left ( 0.2+25x-200x^{2}+675x^{3}-900x^{4}+400x^{5} \right )dx \\  &=\frac{4}{3}\left [ y_{0}+4y_{1}+y_{2} \right ] \\ y_{0}&=y\left ( 0 \right )=0.2 \\ y_{1}&=y\left ( 0.4 \right )=2.456 \\ y_{2}&=y\left ( 0.8 \right )=0.232 \\ y\left ( n \right )&=\frac{0.4}{3}\left ( 0.2+4\times 2.456+0.232 \right ) \\  &=1.367 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 169 The two Eigen values of the matrix [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1\\ 1 & p \end{bmatrix}[/latex]  have a ratio of 3:1 for p = 2. What is another value of p for which the Eigen values have the same ratio of 3:1?
solution: [latex] A=\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1\\ 1 & p \end{bmatrix}[/latex] Let [latex]\lambda _{1}[/latex] and [latex]\lambda _{2}[/latex] be the eigen value of matrix A [latex]\therefore  \;\;   \frac{\lambda _{1}}{\lambda _[2]}=\frac{3}{1}[/latex] for [latex]p=2[/latex] Sum of eigen value [latex] =\lambda _{1}+\lambda _{2}=2+p \;\;...(i)[/latex] Product of eigen value [latex]      =\lambda _{1}\lambda _{2}=2p-1 \;\;...(ii)[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}     \frac{\lambda _{1}}{\lambda _{2}}&=\frac{3}{1} \\ \Rightarrow \;\;    \lambda _{1}&=3\lambda _{2}\\ &\text{From eq. (i)}\\ \Rightarrow \;\;   3\lambda _{2}+\lambda _{2}&=2+p \\      4\lambda _{2}&=2+p \\       \lambda _{2}&=\frac{p+2}{4} \\ \text{From eq. (ii)}\\ \Rightarrow \;\;   3\lambda _{2}^{2}&=2p-1 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; 3\left ( \frac{p+2}{4} \right )^{2}&=2p-1 \\ \Rightarrow    \;\; p&=2,\frac{14}{3}\end{aligned}[/latex] OR [latex] \begin{aligned}   A=\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1\\ 1 & p \end{bmatrix} \\    A-I\lambda &=0 \\ \begin{bmatrix} 2-\lambda & 1\\ 1 & p-\lambda \end{bmatrix}&=0 \\ \left ( 2-\lambda \right )\left ( p-\lambda \right )-1&=0 \\ \lambda ^{2}-\left ( p+2 \right )\lambda +\left ( 2p-1 \right )=0\end{aligned} [/latex] By putting values of p from options. By putting option (D) [latex]\frac{14}{3}[/latex] in above equations gives value 5, [latex]\frac{5}{3}[/latex]. Hence ratio of two eigen values [latex]=\frac{5}{5/3}= 3:1[/latex].

question: Question 170 Consider the following second order linear differential equation: [latex]\frac{d^2 y}{ dx^2}=-12x^{2}+24x-20[/latex] The boundary conditions are: at x = 0, y = 5 and at x = 2, y = 21. The value of y at x = 1 is ____________.
solution: [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d^{2}} y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=-12x^{2}+24x-20[/latex] Integrating both sides wrt. x, [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=-4x^{3}+12x^{2}-20x+c_{1}[/latex] Integrating both sides wrt. x, [latex]y=-x^{4}+4x^{3}-10x^{2}+c_{1}x+c_{2} \;\;...(i)[/latex] At [latex]x=0, \; y=5 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;  5=c_{2}[/latex] At [latex]x=2, \; y=21[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \;\;   21&=-16+32-40+2c_{1}+c_{2} \\    2c_{1}&=21+16-2+40-5 \\    2c_{1}&=40 \\    c_{1}&=20 \\ \Rightarrow \;\;  y&=-x^{4}+4x^{3}-10x^{2}+20x+5\\ &\text{Put } x=1 \\ \Rightarrow \;\;   y&=-1+4-10+20+5 \\    y&=18 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 171 For probability density function of a random variable,x is [latex]\begin{matrix} f(x) &=\frac{x}{4}(4-x^2) &for \;\; 0\leq x\leq 2 \\ &=0 & ohterwise \end{matrix}[/latex] The mean, [latex]\mu _{x}[/latex] of the random variable is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f\left ( x \right ) &=\begin{cases} \frac{x}{4}\left ( 4-x^{2} \right ), & \text{ if } \; \; 0\leq x\leq 2\\ 0, & \text{ if } \; \; Otherwise \end{cases} \\ \mu _{x} &=\int_{0}^{2}xf\left ( x \right )dx \\ \therefore \text{Mean}\: \left ( \mu _{x} \right ) &=\int_{0}^{2}x\frac{x}{4}\left ( 4-x^{2} \right )dx \\ &=\int_{0}^{2}\left ( x^{2}-\frac{x^{4}}{4} \right )dx \\ &=\left [ \frac{x^{3}}{3}-\frac{x^{5}}{20} \right ]_{0}^{2}=\frac{8}{3}-\frac{32}{20}=\frac{16}{15} \\ &=1.066 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 172 Let [latex]\mathbf{A}=\left [ a_{ij} \right ],\; \; \; 1\leq i, \; j\leq n[/latex] with [latex]n\geq 3\; and\; a_{ij}=i.j[/latex]. The rank of A is:
solution: Rank of A=1 Because each row will be scalar multiple of first row.So we will get only one-zero row in row Echeleaon form of A. Alternative: Rank of A=1 Because all the minors of order greater than 1 will be zero.

question: Question 173 [latex]\lim_{x\rightarrow \infty }\left ( 1+\frac{1}{x} \right )^{2x}[/latex] is equal to
solution: [latex]   y=\: \lim_{x\rightarrow \infty }\left ( 1+\frac{1}{x} \right )^{2x} [/latex] [latex]   \log y = \lim_{x\rightarrow \infty }2x\log \left ( 1+\frac{1}{x} \right )[/latex] Which is in the form of [latex]\infty \times 0[/latex]. To convert this into [latex]\frac{0}{0}[/latex] form, we rewrite as, [latex]\Rightarrow   \log y= \lim_{x\rightarrow \infty }\frac{2\log \left ( 1+\frac{1}{x} \right )}{1/x}[/latex] Now is in [latex]\frac{0}{0}[/latex] form. Using L'Hospital's Rule, [latex]\begin{aligned}   \log y&=\lim_{x\rightarrow \infty }\frac{\frac{2\times -\frac{1}{x^{2}}}{1+\frac{1}{x}}}{-\frac{1}{x^{2}}} \\   \log y&=\lim_{x\rightarrow \infty }\frac{2}{1+\frac{1}{x}}=2 \\ \therefore  \;\;  y&= e^{2}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 174 Given , [latex]i=\sqrt{-1}[/latex], the value of the definite integral, [latex]I=\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{\cos x+i\sin x}{\cos x-i\sin x}dx[/latex] is:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I&=\int_{0}^{\pi /2}\frac{\cos x+i\sin x}{\cos x-i\sin x}dx \\  &=\int_{0}^{\pi /2}\frac{e^{ix}}{e^{-ix}}dx=e^{2ix}dx \\  &=\frac{1}{2i}\left [ e^{2ix} \right ]_{0}^{\pi /2} \\ &=\frac{1}{2i}\left [ e^{i\pi }-1 \right ] \\ &=\frac{1}{2i}\left ( -1-1 \right ) \\  &=-\frac{1}{i}=i \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 175 In Newton-Raphson iterative method, the initial guess value ( [latex]x_{ini}[/latex]) is considered as zero while finding the roots of the euation:[latex]f(x)=-2+6x-4x^{2}+0.5x^{3}[/latex]. The correction, [latex]\Delta x[/latex], to be added to [latex]x_{ini}[/latex] in the first iteration is____________.
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned}   f\left ( x \right )&=-2+6x-4x^{2}+0.5x^{3} \\    {f}'\left ( x \right )&=6-8x+1.5x^{2} \\    x_{ini}&=0\\ \text{By Newton }&\text{Raphson Method,}\\    x_{1}&=x_{ini}-\frac{f\left ( x_{ini} \right )}{{f}'\left ( x_{ini} \right )} \\    &=  0-\frac{-2}{6} \\ \Rightarrow    \;\;x_{1}&=\frac{1}{3} \\ \therefore \;\;  \Delta x&=x_{1}-x_{ini}=\frac{1}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 177 The directional derivative of the field [latex]u(x,y,z)=x^{2}-3xy[/latex] in the direction of the vector [latex](\hat{i}+\hat{j}-2\hat{k})[/latex] and point (2, -1, 4) is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}u (x, y, z)&=x^{2}-3yz \\  \triangledown u&=2x\hat{i}-3z\hat{j}-3y\hat{k} \\  \triangledown ul_{at\: \left ( 2,\, -1\, 4 \right )}&=4\hat{i}+12\hat{j}-3\hat{k}\\ &\text{Directional derivative}\\   &= \left ( 4\hat{i}+12\hat{j}-3\hat{k} \right ).\frac{\hat{i}+\hat{j}-\hat{k}}{\sqrt{6}} \\   &= \frac{4-12-6}{\sqrt{6}} =-\frac{14}{\sqrt{6}} \\   &= -\frac{7\sqrt{6}}{3}=-5.715\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 178 Consider the following complex function: [latex]f(z)=\frac{9}{(z-1)(z+2)^{2}}[/latex] Which of the following is one of the residues of the above function?
solution: [latex]f(z)[/latex] has poles at [latex]z=1, -2[/latex] Residue of [latex]f(z)[/latex] at [/latex](z=1)[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}  &=\lim_{z\rightarrow 1}\left ( z-1 \right )f\left ( z \right ) \\   &=\lim_{z\rightarrow 1}\frac{9}{\left ( z+2 \right )^{2}} \\&=1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Residue of [latex]f(z)[/latex] at [latex](z=-2)[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}  &=\lim_{z\rightarrow 2}\frac{d}{dz^{2-1}}\left [ \left ( z+2 \right )^{2}f\left ( z \right ) \right ] \\   &=\lim_{z\rightarrow 2}\frac{d}{dz}\left ( \frac{9}{z-1} \right ) \\   &=\lim_{z\rightarrow 2}\left ( \frac{9}{\left ( z-1 \right )^{2}} \right ) \\   &=-1\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 179 Consider the following differential equation: [latex]x(ydx+xdy)\cos \frac{y}{x}=y(xdy-ydx)\sin \frac{y}{x}[/latex] Which of the following is the solution of the above equation (c is an arbitrary constant)?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x\left ( ydx+xdy \right )\cos \frac{y}{x}&=y\left ( xdy-ydx \right )\sin \frac{y}{x} \\ \frac{ydx+xdy}{xdy-ydx}&=\frac{y}{x}\tan \frac{y}{x}\\ \text{Let }  y&=v \cdot x \\   dy&=vdx+xdv \\ \frac{vxdx+vxdx+x^{2}dv}{vxdx+x^{2}dv-vxdx}&=v\tan v \\ \frac{xdv+2vdx}{xdv}&=v\tan v \\ 1+\frac{2v}{x}\frac{dx}{dv}&=v\tan v \\ \frac{2v}{x}\frac{dx}{dv}&=v\tan v-1 \\ 2\frac{dx}{x}&=\left ( \tan v-\frac{1}{v} \right )dv \end{aligned}[/latex] Integrating both sides. [latex]\begin{aligned}2\log x&=\log \left | \sec v \right |-\log v+\log c \\ \Rightarrow \;\; x^{2}&=\frac{c\sec v}{v} \\ \Rightarrow \;\; x^{2}\frac{y}{x}&=c\sec \frac{y}{x} \\ \Rightarrow \;\; xy\cos \frac{y}{x}&=c \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 180 The quadratic equation [latex]x^{2}-4x+4=0[/latex] is to be solved numerically, starting with the initial guess [latex]x_0=3[/latex]. The Newton-Raphson method is applied once to get a new estimate and then the Secant method is applied once using the initial guess and this new estimate. The estimated value of the root after the application of the Secant method is __________.
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned}  f\left ( x \right )&=x^{2}-4x+4 \\   {f}'\left ( x \right )&=2x-4 \\   x_{0}&=3 \\   f\left ( 3 \right )&=1, {f}'\left ( 3 \right )=2 \\ \text{By Newton } & \text{Rapshon method,}\\   x_{1}&=x_{0}-\frac{f\left ( x_{0} \right )}{{f}'_{x_{0}}} \\    &=3-\frac{1}{2}=\frac{5}{2} \\   f\left ( \frac{5}{2} \right )&=\frac{25}{4}-10+4=\frac{1}{4} \\ & \text{By Secant method,}\\   x_{2}&=x_{1}-\frac{\left ( x_{1}-x_{0} \right )f\left ( x_{1} \right )}{f\left ( x_{1} \right )-f\left ( x_{0} \right )} \\    &=\frac{f_{1}x_{0}-f_{0}x_{1}}{f_{1}-f_{0}} \\    &=\frac{\left ( \frac{1}{4}\times 3 \right )-\left ( 1\times \frac{5}{2} \right )}{\frac{1}{4}-1} \\    &=\frac{7}{3}=2.33 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 181 The smallest and largest Eigen values of the following matrix are : [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 3 &-2 &2 \\ 4 &-4 &6 \\ 2 &-3 &5 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]
solution: For eigen values [latex]\begin{aligned} \left | A-\lambda I \right |&=0 \\ \begin{vmatrix} 3-\lambda & -2 &2 \\ 4 & -4-\lambda &6 \\ 2 & -3 & 5-\lambda \end{vmatrix}&=0 \\ \left ( 3-\lambda \right )\left ( -20+4\lambda -5\lambda +\lambda ^{2}+18 \right ) &\\ +2 \left ( 20-4\lambda -12 \right )+2\left ( -12+8+2\lambda \right )&=0 \\  \lambda ^{3}-4\lambda ^{2}+5\lambda -2&=0\end{aligned}[/latex] Only 1 and 2 satisfy this equation. [latex]\lambda =1,\: 1,\: 2[/latex] Hence, Smallest eigen value =1 and Largest eigen value =2

question: Question 182 Consider the following probability mass function (p.m.f) of a random variable X : [latex]p(x,q)=\begin{cases} q & \text{ if } X=0\\ 1-q& \text{ if } X=1 \\ 0 & \text otherwise \end{cases}[/latex] If q = 0.4, the variance of X is _______.
solution: Given, [latex]\; \; \; \; q=0.4[/latex] Required value [latex]=V\left ( X \right )=E\left ( X^{2} \right )-\left [ E\left ( X \right ) \right ]^{2}[/latex] [latex]E\left ( X \right )=\sum_{i}^{}\, X_{i}p_{i}=0\times 0.4+1\times 0.6=0.6[/latex] [latex]E\left ( X^{2} \right )=\sum_{i}^{}\, X_{i}^{2}p_{i}=0^{2}\times 0.4+1^{2}\times 0.6=0.6[/latex] [latex]\therefore \; \; \; V\left ( X \right )=E\left ( X^{2} \right )-\left [ E\left ( X \right ) \right ]^{2}=0.6-0.36=0.24[/latex]

question: Question 183 The integral [latex]\int_{x_1}^{x_2}x^{2}dx[/latex] with [latex]{x_1} \gt {x_2} \gt 0[/latex] is evaluated analytically as well as numerically using a single application of the trapezoidal rule. If I is the exact value of the integral obtained analytically and J is the approximate  value  obtained  using  the trapezoidal rule, which of the following statements is correct about their relationship?
solution: Exact value is computed by integration which follows the exact shape of graph while computing the area. Whereas, in Trapezoidal rule, the lines joining each points are considered straight lines which is not the exact variation of graph all the time like as shown figure. [latex]\therefore    J\gt I [/latex] OR [latex]    \text{Error } =-\frac{h^{3}}{12}{f}''\left ( \Im \right )\times n_{i}[/latex] Here, [latex]   f\left ( x \right )=x^{2}[/latex] or, [latex]   {f}'\left ( x \right )=2x[/latex] or, [latex]   {f}''\left ( x \right )=2\gt 0[/latex] Since [latex]{f}''\left ( x \right )[/latex] is positive, the error is negative. Since error = exact-approximate. [latex]=I-J[/latex] and since error is negative in this case [latex]J\gt I[/latex] is true.

options.D: Insufficient data to determine the relationship

question: Question 185 The rank of matrix [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 6 &0 &4 &4 \\ -2 &14 &8 &18 \\ 14 &-14 &0 &10 \\ \end{bmatrix}[/latex] is:

Question 189 [latex]z=\frac{2-3i}{-5+i}[/latex] can be expressed as

question: Question 190 The determinant of matrix [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 &2 &3 \\ 1 &0 &3 &0 \\ 2 &3 &0 &1 \\ 3 &0 &1 &2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] is__________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta &=\begin{vmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 & 3\\ 1 & 0 & 3 & 0\\ 2 & 3 & 0 & 1\\ 3 & 0 & 1 & 2 \end{vmatrix} \\ R_{4} & \rightarrow R_{4}-R_{2}-R_{3} \\ \Delta &=\begin{vmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 & 3\\ 1 & 0 & 3 & 0\\ 2 & 3 & 0 & 1\\ 0 & -3 & -2 &1 \end{vmatrix} \\ R_{4} & \rightarrow R_{4}+3R_{1} \\ \Delta &=\begin{vmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 & 3\\ 1 & 0 & 3 & 0\\ 2 & 3 & 0 & 1\\ 0 & 0 & 4 & 10 \end{vmatrix} \\ R_{3} & \rightarrow R_{3}-3R_{1} \\ \Delta &=\begin{vmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 & 3\\ 1 & 0 & 3 & 0\\ 2 & 0 & -6 & -8\\ 0 & 0 & 4 & 10 \end{vmatrix} \end{aligned}[/latex] interchanging column 1 and column 2 and taking transpose, [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta &=-\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 & 0\\ 0 & 1 & 2 & 0\\ 2 & 3 & -6 & 4\\ 3 & 0 & -8 & 10 \end{vmatrix} \\  &=-1\times \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 2 & 0\\ 3 & -6 & 4\\ 0 & -8 & 10 \end{vmatrix} \\  &=1\times \left \{ 1\left ( -60+32 \right )+2\left ( 0-30 \right ) \right \} \\  &=-\left ( -28-60 \right )=88\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 192 A traffic office imposes on an average 5 number of penalties daily on traffic violators. Assume that the number of penalties on different days is independent and follows a Poisson distribution. The probability that there will be less than 4 penalties in a day is ___________
solution: Mean [latex]\; \; \; \; \; \lambda =5[/latex] [latex]P\left ( x \lt 4 \right )=p\left ( x=0 \right )+p\left ( x=1 \right )+p\left ( x=2 \right )+p\left ( x=3 \right )[/latex] [latex]=\frac{e^{-5}s^{0}}{0!}+\frac{e^{-5}5^{1}}{1!}+\frac{e^{-5}5^{2}}{1!}+\frac{e^{-5}5^{3}}{3!}[/latex] [latex]=e^{-5}\left [ 1+5+\frac{25}{2}+\frac{125}{6} \right ]=e^{-5}\left ( \frac{118}{3} \right )[/latex] [latex]=0.265[/latex]

question: Question 193 With reference to the conventional Cartesian (x, y) coordinate system, the vertices of a triangle have the following coordinates: [latex]\left ( x_{1},y_{1} \right )=\left ( 1,0 \right )[/latex]; [latex]\left ( x_{2},y_{2} \right )=\left ( 2,2 \right )[/latex]; and [latex]\left ( x_{3},y_{3} \right )=\left ( 4,3\right )[/latex]. The area of the triangle is equal to
solution: Area of triangle is [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{2}\left [ x_{1}\left ( y_{1}-y_{3} \right )+x_{2}\left ( y_{3}-y_{1} \right )+x_{2}\left ( y_{1}-y_{2} \right ) \right ] \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left [ 1\left ( 2-3 \right )+2\left ( 3-0 \right )+4\left ( 0-2 \right ) \right ] \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left [ -1+6-8 \right ]=\frac{3}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]
